question: It is true that the addition operator (+) in Python is used to add two numbers.
It is false that the exponentiation operator (**) is used for division.
The modulus operator (%) returns the quotient of two numbers.
The floor division operator (//) in Python removes the decimal part of a division result.
It is false that the multiplication operator (*) cannot be used with strings.
The comparison operator (==) checks if two values are exactly the same.
The operator (!=) returns True if both values are equal.
The logical AND operator (and) returns True if both conditions are True.
The logical OR operator (or) returns True only if both conditions are True.
The NOT operator (not) inverts the Boolean value of a condition.
Bitwise operators work at the binary level in Python.
The bitwise AND operator (&) returns 1 if either bit is 1.
The bitwise OR operator (|) returns 1 if either bit is 1.
The membership operator 'in' checks if a value is present in a sequence.
The membership operator 'not in' returns True if the value exists in the sequence.
Identity operators check whether two variables refer to the same object in memory.
The 'is' operator returns True if two variables store the same values, regardless of memory location.
Operator precedence determines the order in which expressions are evaluated in Python.
Parentheses () have the lowest precedence among all Python operators.
The expression 2 + 3 * 4 evaluates to 14 because multiplication has higher precedence.
Using parentheses in an expression changes the order of evaluation.
The exponentiation operator (**) has a lower precedence than multiplication (*).
In Python, x += 5 is equivalent to x = x + 5.
The assignment operator '=' is used for comparison between two values.
Python supports array operators as built-in functionality.
NumPy is commonly used for array operations in Python.
Using 'is not' returns True when two variables refer to the same object in memory.
The floor division operator (//) returns a float result always.
The modulus operator (%) can be used to determine if a number is even or odd.
The NOT (~) operator inverts Boolean values but does not work on integers.
Using parentheses in expressions can override operator precedence.
Python supports the use of multiple assignment operators in a single statement.
The logical AND operator (and) has higher precedence than the logical OR operator (or).
The expression 5 == '5' evaluates to True in Python.
The greater than operator (>) and the less than operator (<) have the same precedence.
